channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: China’s Deflationary Woes Continue Unabated
item.description: China’s deflationary pressures persisted in August, with a gauge of consumer prices slipping back into contraction as an uncertain growth outlook dents sentiment.

item.title: A federal judge late on Tuesday blocked President Trump from removing Lisa Cook from the Federal Reserve Board of Governors while a lawsuit challenging her firing proceeds
item.description: The order allows Cook to remain on the central bank’s board for now while her legal challenge proceeds.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Wheeler

item.title: Fitch Ratings Nudges Up Global Growth Outlook for 2025
item.description: Fitch Ratings has nudged up its world growth outlook for 2025 despite growing gloom about the U.S. economic outlook, saying China and Europe aren’t as downbeat as earlier thought.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: Census Bureau data show that average U.S. households haven’t gained ground economically since the Covid-19 pandemic struck
item.description: High-income households fared better than others, while women lost ground to men, according to Census Bureau data.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: U.S. added over 900,000 fewer jobs than previously thought
item.description: The revised job numbers show a significantly weaker labor picture than earlier reports indicated.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: French Industrial Output Retreated in July
item.description: Production was down 1.1% on month, with output falling in transport manufacturing, electrical equipment and pharmaceuticals.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: New polling by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York shows American workers’ confidence in finding a new job if they lose the position they currently hold has hit a record low
item.description: Two new surveys from the New York Fed and Conference Board add to signs of a faltering labor market.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The U.S. labor market would be barely growing without job gains in health services. Eight charts look at employment and the American workforce.
item.description: One danger: Coming Medicaid cuts pose a threat to health services.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: German Industrial Production Rebounds Despite Falling Exports
item.description: Industrial output rose 1.3% on month despite a further plunge in exports to the U.S., indicating the sector’s resilience in the face of tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: When President Trump unveiled his EU trade deal, businesses across the bloc thought it would end months of uncertainty. Less than two months on, frustration is growing in Europe.
item.description: European equipment manufacturers want changes to the July trade deal after being hit by the White House’s expanding steel tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Kim Mackrael

item.title: Uncertainty over the fate of President Trump’s duties spurs firms to see whether they could claw back billions of dollars
item.description: Uncertainty over the fate of President Trump’s duties spurs firms to see whether they could claw back billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Paul Berger

item.title: How far and how fast will Fed officials move to keep cutting rates after September?
item.description: Weak summer hiring has traders betting on consecutive rate cuts through year-end, but inflation risks remain a wild card.
item.dc:creator: Jack Pitcher

item.title: The IT unemployment rate fell to 4.5% in August from 5.5% the prior month. But there are still fewer jobs available for tech workers, especially those who don’t specialize in AI.
item.description: Beyond the red-hot area of AI hiring, the job market for much of information-technology is still getting smaller, recent analysis shows.
item.dc:creator: Belle Lin

item.title: U.S. job growth continued to slow down in August, a sign that the labor market is deteriorating markedly
item.description: The government revised its numbers from earlier in the summer and said the economy lost a net 13,000 jobs in June. It was the first such decline since December 2020.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Canada unexpectedly shed jobs for a second month running in August
item.description: Employers shed 65,500 jobs last month, the highest since the start of 2022, official data shows. This is likely to lift rate-cut expectations.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Eurozone Posts Marginal Economic Growth in 2Q, But ECB Rate Cut Remains Unlikely
item.description: Across the 20 nations that share the euro, GDP was 0.1% higher than the first quarter, a sharp slowdown from the 0.6% expansion in the first three months of the year.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: German Manufacturing Orders Drop as Foreign Demand Takes Hit
item.description: Foreign orders fell 3.1%, though there was a steeper 3.8% decline for orders inside the eurozone, and domestic orders declined 2.5%.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: The U.S. is getting ready to start a renegotiation of its largest free trade deal—the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement.
item.description: Public consultations on the key U.S. trade deal with Mexico and Canada will be the first act in what is likely to be a lengthy and contentious review.
item.dc:creator: Vipal Monga

item.title: President Trump’s campaign to bring the Federal Reserve under White House control faces a major test Thursday when the Senate weighs confirming Stephen Miran to the central bank’s board of governors
item.description: One of the president’s top advisers, Stephen Miran, is almost assured of confirmation as he appears before a Senate committee on Thursday
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Malaysia’s Central Bank Keeps Policy Rate Steady
item.description: Bank Negara Malaysia on Thursday kept the overnight policy rate at 2.75% after July’s first cut in five years, matching expectations from seven economists polled by The Wall Street Journal.
item.dc:creator: Ying Xian Wong

item.title: Swiss Inflation Holds Steady as SNB Mulls Rate Cut Below Zero
item.description: Inflation stayed low in August, keeping the country’s central bank on guard as it considers cutting its key interest rate to below zero later this month.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Accelerates, Priming Continued Rate Pause by ECB
item.description: Annual inflation picked up pace a little in the eurozone last month, cementing expectations that the ECB will leave interest rates unchanged next week.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Eurozone Unemployment Rate Fell To Match Record Low In July
item.description: The result comes despite weak economic growth, underpinning expectations that the ECB will leave its key interest rate unchanged next week.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending
item.description: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending.
item.dc:creator: Alison Sider

item.title: What is mortgage occupancy fraud—an offense of which Trump officials are accusing a Fed governor?
item.description: Lenders typically offer better terms for primary residences, including lower interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: German Consumers Feel Ever Gloomier as Economy Slumps
item.description: Concerns around unemployment drove the cautious mood among German shoppers.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Canada needs a big lift in construction if it is to close the housing shortage it faces over the next decade, a report by the country’s budget watchdog suggested
item.description: Canada requires a total of 3.2 million new housing units by 2035, the Office of the Parliamentary Budget Officer projects.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: U.K. Consumers Sunnier as BOE Cuts Rates But Economic Fears Remain
item.description: U.K. consumers felt a little better about their finances this month as the Bank of England lowered borrowing costs, though sentiment remains weak amid wider economic turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Hovnanian Profit Sinks Due to Sales Incentives Amid Stagnant Housing Market
item.description: The home builder said it used widespread incentives, particularly mortgage buydowns, to make homes affordable for buyers and said it was emphasizing “pace over price” to sell inventory.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas G. Miller

item.title: Home sales climbed 2% in July while prices eased
item.description: The unexpected pickup in sales activity reflected a slight improvement in affordability as home-price growth slows.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Housing construction in the U.S. jumped much more than expected in July, reflecting a recovery in the multifamily market as developers respond to demand for rental housing
item.description: Apartment construction is climbing steadily, while the construction of single-family homes is declining.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Anxious shoppers, concerned about inflation and their personal finances, are cutting their spending to focus on essentials
item.description: Generic brands and bulk buying are on the rise as shoppers find themselves in a summer of economic uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Khan

item.title: Consumer-Confidence Survey Improved in July
item.description: The Conference Board’s consumer-confidence index climbed to 97.2, from 95.2 in June. But American consumers’ economic mood remained clouded by tariff and labor market concerns.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Ireland’s Economy Contracts as U.S. Front-Running Cools
item.description: A surge in exports to the U.S. which led Ireland to far outstrip the growth rates of other rich economies waned in the three months through June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Capital Account: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans
item.description: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Key Rate Again as Economy Slows
item.description: Friday marked the second-straight time the Bank of Russia cut its interest rate after it lowered borrowing costs in early June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
